Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.perspective_relevance: As an expert in French Election Law and electoral procedures, I bring an understanding of the constitutional constraints on dissolution, the historical context of legislative dissolutions, the mechanics and political implications of a snap election, and the incentives/disincentives facing a French president under conditions of parliamentary deadlock. I can assess both the legal feasibility and the political calculus involved in calling new elections.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.status_quo: No snap election is called. The National Assembly remains fragmented, with Macron appointing successive prime ministers from the centrist or moderate right, relying on shifting alliances and policy concessions to survive confidence votes. The government limps through until at least 2026, despite instability.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Article 12 of the French Constitution allows the president to dissolve the National Assembly only once within a given year. Macron dissolved the Assembly in June 2024, so a new dissolution was only possible after June 2025. With less than three months to 2026, the legal window is short and the norm is to avoid multiple dissolutions in quick succession.

Decreases probability. Historically, dissolutions are rare (only six since 1958), and two within 18 months is unprecedented. The political cost of repeated dissolutions is high, and the last dissolution (2024) is widely considered a political blunder by Macron.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Parliamentary Instability (Frequent No Confidence Votes, PM Turnover)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The government has seen five prime ministers in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, and persistent budget crises. If the government becomes completely unworkable (e.g., no budget can pass, total deadlock), dissolution may be viewed as the only option.

Decreases probability. Multiple sources, including a Le Figaro/Odysseus poll, show a strong majority of the French public opposes another dissolution before 2027, seeing the last one as a mistake. Macron is personally unpopular and his coalition weakened; a new election would likely further erode his influence.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Pressure (RN and NFP Calls for Dissolution)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Both the far-right National Rally and elements of the left are calling for dissolution, betting that new elections could improve their standing. However, Macron has little incentive to comply, given the risk to his own coalition.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Electoral Law Incentives for Status Quo
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French semi-presidential system is designed to encourage cohabitation and compromise in periods of deadlock. The president can focus on foreign affairs while governments come and go, as happened in the late 1980s and 1990s.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Imminence of 2026/2027 Elections and Political Calendar
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. With the next scheduled elections not far off, and the risk that another dissolution would be seen as chaotic and anti-democratic, inertia favors muddling through rather than another snap vote.

Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.no_scenario: Despite ongoing parliamentary instability, Macron continues to appoint compromise prime ministers who rely on shifting alliances to survive, perhaps using Article 49.3 to force budgets through. The government faces repeated no-confidence motions, but no single bloc can unite to force a workable alternative, and with public opinion hostile to more elections, Macron refrains from a new dissolution before 2026.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.yes_scenario: The government reaches a point of total paralysis: the Assembly fails to pass any budget, repeated no-confidence votes unseat multiple prime ministers in rapid succession, and major social unrest (e.g., general strikes, mass protests) erupts. Macron, seeing no alternative and under intense pressure from all sides—including the EU over fiscal targets—calls a new snap election in a last-ditch attempt to break the deadlock before 2026.
Election Law (French Electoral Procedure.final_reasoning: The base rate for a second dissolution within such a short period is extremely low, and the French legal and political tradition discourages rapid-fire elections. The 2024 dissolution is widely seen as a political error, further reducing Macron’s appetite for another. Although government instability is acute (five PMs in two years, constant budget crises), the system is designed to muddle through and tolerate minority/short-lived governments. Public opinion is strongly against a new dissolution, and Macron’s personal and systemic incentives align in favor of enduring instability rather than risking a further loss of legitimacy or a stronger showing by the opposition in new elections. Only a complete breakdown (e.g., an ungovernable parliament, EU/IMF intervention, or mass unrest) could push Macron to call another snap election, but even then, the short time window and the likelihood that any new election would worsen the deadlock make this scenario unlikely. Therefore, the probability is low, but not zero: I judge a 15% chance Macron will call another snap legislative election before 2026.

Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Election Law, specifically in the French constitutional provisions (notably Article 12 of the French Constitution), I bring a deep understanding of the legal mechanisms, historical patterns, and political calculus surrounding the dissolution of the National Assembly and the calling of snap elections. Article 12 gives the President the sole prerogative to dissolve the Assembly, but only once per year, and political as well as constitutional norms strongly influence such decisions. This expertise helps weigh institutional inertia, procedural constraints, and the practical risks and incentives for Macron.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.status_quo: No snap election is called; the political crisis continues to be managed through repeated changes of prime minister, precarious minority governments, and legislative gridlock. Macron avoids another dissolution within his term.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The constitution only allows one dissolution per year, and Macron already used this tool in July 2024. The legal window only reopened in July 2025, leaving a brief period until the 2026 deadline. Snap dissolutions are rare due to their destabilizing effect and the political cost if seen as a last resort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Incentives and Risks for Macron
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Macron's previous dissolution backfired, leading to a fractured parliament and loss of government control. Recent polling and analysis suggest that another snap election would likely not result in a more favorable configuration for him or his coalition, and might further strengthen the far-right or left. The negative public perception (cited: 62% oppose another dissolution) makes another snap election politically risky.

Increases probability: The unprecedented turnover of prime ministers, repeated no-confidence votes, inability to pass budgets, and ongoing protests do push toward the use of the dissolution tool as a way to break deadlock. Multiple news reports suggest rising calls for another election from both opposition and some in Macron's camp.

Increases probability: Both the far-right (Le Pen/National Rally) and the far-left (La France Insoumise) are vocally demanding new elections, hoping to capitalize on Macron's weakness. However, they cannot force dissolution; only Macron can decide.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Dissolutions in the Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Historically, dissolutions are rare, especially two within 18 months. The last time two happened so close together was in periods of extreme crisis (1968, 1997).

Decreases probability: The latest surveys show a clear majority of the French public opposes another dissolution before the next presidential election, reflecting fear of further instability. Macron is sensitive to legitimacy concerns, especially with his popularity at record lows.

Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.no_scenario: Despite repeated government collapses and ongoing mass protests, Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers and tries to cobble together shifting coalitions or technocratic caretaker governments. He calculates that another snap election would only worsen legislative fragmentation or hand power to the extremes, and thus chooses not to dissolve the Assembly again before the 2026 deadline. France stumbles on in gridlock until the scheduled elections in 2027.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.yes_scenario: Political and economic crises escalate—perhaps due to a failed budget, market panic, or massive, sustained protests—leading to a complete paralysis in government. Macron determines that no viable government can be formed and, facing mounting public pressure and perhaps a constitutional impasse (e.g., inability to pass any legislation or budget), he invokes Article 12 again in late 2025, calling a new snap election despite the risks.
Election Law (Constitutional Law Article.final_reasoning: While France is indeed facing extraordinary political instability—five prime ministers in two years, successive no-confidence votes, and persistent mass protests—the combination of constitutional, political, and public opinion barriers makes it unlikely Macron will call another snap legislative election before January 1, 2026. The base rate for consecutive dissolutions is very low in French Fifth Republic history, and Macron's previous use of Article 12 led to even greater instability and backlash. Current polls and elite commentary point to strong public opposition to another dissolution, and there is little evidence that an election would resolve the deadlock in Macron’s favor. The only scenario in which another dissolution becomes likely is a complete constitutional or fiscal crisis (e.g., total inability to pass a budget, or external market pressure threatening default), but even in that case, Macron may still weigh the risk of empowering the extremes and opt for continued caretaker governments. Given the limited time window and high barriers, the probability should be below 20%, but not zero due to the ongoing crisis.

Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planning), I am trained to weigh base rates, structural incentives, and the interplay of institutional constraints with leader psychology. France’s semi-presidential system, history of parliamentary instability, and the unique powers vested in the presidency to dissolve the National Assembly are all directly relevant. Scenario planning enables me to envision both likely and edge-case developments, while grounding my forecast in historical precedent and structural analysis.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.status_quo: No new snap legislative election is called before the constitutional minimum one-year waiting period from the last dissolution (July 2024), and Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers or pursue ad hoc coalitions, despite ongoing instability.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron cannot dissolve the National Assembly again until July 2025, and this restricts his options for most of the time window. Even after July, the time to act before 2026 is short.

Increases probability. The Assembly is split three ways, no bloc can govern, there have been five prime ministers in under two years, multiple no-confidence votes, and persistent failure to pass budgets, all increasing the incentive to seek a new mandate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public Fatigue and Political Risk Aversion
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Polling and political commentary indicate that both the French public and political elites are wary of another snap election after the 2024 experience, with 62% of the public against another dissolution and concern that repeated elections erode political legitimacy.

Decreases probability. Macron’s previous snap call was widely seen as a political error, weakening his position. He is likely highly risk-averse to repeating this mistake and may prefer muddling through with minority or technocratic governments.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Opposition Pressure (Le Pen/National Rally Calls for Elections)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The far right and parts of the left are publicly calling for dissolution, hoping to benefit from the instability. This adds pressure, especially if another government collapses.

Increases probability. France faces mass protests, strikes, a debt crisis, and failed budgets—structural pressures that could push Macron to dissolve if no government can pass a budget or maintain legitimacy.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Elections in France
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Historically, dissolutions are rare: only 5 since 1958, and rarely twice within a single presidential term. The Fifth Republic is designed to avoid chronic instability.
Decreases probability. Even if Macron decides to dissolve, the practical window (July–December 2025) is extremely limited, requiring a strong trigger event.

Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.no_scenario: Despite repeated government collapses and ongoing protests, Macron continues to cycle prime ministers or forms a technocratic caretaker government, relying on emergency decrees or partial deals to pass essential budgets. The risk of another snap election is judged too high by both Macron and the political establishment, given the public’s fatigue and the potential to further empower the extremes. Macron seeks to 'ride out' the remainder of the time window to 2026.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.yes_scenario: After another failed budget or a major government collapse (possibly through a lost confidence vote for PM Lecornu), Macron, out of options and facing market panic or ungovernability, dissolves the Assembly between July 2025 and the end of the year. He gambles that a new election, possibly under pressure from mass mobilizations or EU fiscal threats, is the only way to restore stability or legitimacy.
Political Risk Analysis (Scenario Planni.final_reasoning: The situation in France is highly unstable: there have been five prime ministers in less than two years, persistent failure to pass budgets, mass protests, and a deadlocked parliament. Structurally, this increases the likelihood of a snap election. However, several powerful constraints pull the other way: (1) Macron cannot constitutionally dissolve until July 2025, leaving only a ~6-month window; (2) the historical base rate for repeated dissolutions is extremely low; (3) public and elite appetite for another snap election is minimal, with strong evidence of fatigue and backlash from the 2024 experience; (4) Macron’s own risk calculus is likely cautious after being burned by the last dissolution. While a further government crisis or external shock (e.g., budget standoff, EU/IMF pressure) could force his hand, these would have to occur and escalate rapidly post-July. The most likely scenario is muddling through with unstable or technocratic governments rather than risking a new election. Nonetheless, the risk is non-trivial given the depth of instability and the very real possibility of a total legislative impasse. Weighing all factors, a probability in the low–mid 20s best reflects the base rate, status quo bias, and live tail risk.

Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Political Risk Analysis and Crisis Decisionmaking Models, I focus on institutional constraints, elite incentives, base rates of parliamentary dissolutions, and the political calculus of leaders under duress. My approach emphasizes the interplay between structural deadlock, leadership agency, and the risk aversion/political survival instincts that motivate snap election calls in parliamentary systems.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.status_quo: No further snap legislative election is called before 2026; France continues to operate with a deadlocked parliament and unstable minority governments, but President Macron does not dissolve the National Assembly again.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. French constitution forbids dissolution until at least July 2025, leaving only a narrow 5.5-month window for a legal snap election call.

Decreases probability. Recent snap election widely seen as a 'political error'; 62% of French public now opposes another dissolution before 2027, and Macron’s authority has been eroded. Repeating the same move could further delegitimize him and his coalition.

Mixed, but leans toward decrease. Macron and his allies risk even worse outcomes in a new snap election, and opposition forces (esp. National Rally and left) are more likely to push for dissolution if they think they will win. Macron’s current incentive is to avoid another dissolution unless absolutely necessary.

Increases probability. France has cycled through five prime ministers in two years, with repeated failed budgets and confidence votes. If a government cannot be formed or repeatedly falls, the pressure for another dissolution rises, especially if the country becomes ungovernable.

Increases probability. Ongoing austerity, debt concerns, and mass protests (e.g. 1 million marching in September, general strikes) increase the risk of a legitimacy crisis that could make snap elections seem like a necessary reset.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Elections in France
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Even in periods of instability, multiple snap dissolutions in such rapid succession are rare in the Fifth Republic. The historical frequency of two dissolutions within 18 months is extremely low.

Decreases probability. As the presidential election approaches, politicians (including those opposed to Macron) may prefer to maintain the current deadlock rather than risk a parliamentary reshuffle that could empower rivals ahead of the main contest.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Legal/Procedural Risk: Macron Leaves Office Before 2026
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. If Macron were to resign or be otherwise removed before calling a new snap election, the question would resolve 'No'. Currently, this is a low probability but not impossible scenario.

Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.no_scenario: Despite continued parliamentary deadlock, budget crises, and public protests, Macron chooses not to dissolve the National Assembly again due to the political cost, unpopularity of another snap election, risk of even worse results for his coalition, and the institutional inertia of the French system. Minority governments persist via ad-hoc deals, or the Assembly remains gridlocked until the scheduled 2027 elections. Macron may shift focus to foreign policy and ride out the deadlock, hoping to avoid further delegitimization.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.yes_scenario: Following another failed budget, a major government collapse, or an extreme escalation of public unrest (e.g. general strike, mass unrest making the country ungovernable), Macron determines that governing is impossible. Despite the risks, he calls a new snap election in late 2025, hoping to break the deadlock—even though public opinion is against it. Alternatively, a combination of elite and public pressure, including possibly from coalition partners or the opposition, forces his hand.
Political Risk Analysis (Crisis Decision.final_reasoning: While the situation in France is very unstable—five PMs in two years, repeated failed governments, mass protests, and budget crises—the structural and political barriers to another snap election before 2026 are high. The constitutional one-year rule means no dissolution is possible until July 2025, leaving only a brief window. Macron has already been punished in public opinion and in his party’s standing for the previous dissolution, and surveys show a strong majority oppose another snap election. The base rate for such rapid repetitions of dissolutions in France is extremely low, and Macron's personal incentive is to avoid further damage to his legacy. Although the risk is not negligible—if the country becomes entirely ungovernable, or another government collapses spectacularly, a snap election could be seen as the only way out—the default scenario remains muddling through with weak minority governments until the regular election cycle. The combination of public opposition, elite self-preservation, and historical precedent for riding out deadlock makes a 'No' outcome noticeably likelier, though the risk is much higher than in a typical period of French politics. I estimate the probability Macron calls another snap legislative election before 2026 at 22%.

Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.perspective_relevance: As a rational choice theorist in political science, I focus on the incentives, constraints, and expected utility calculations facing key actors, particularly President Macron. My analysis emphasizes base rates of snap dissolutions in the Fifth Republic, the costs/benefits of calling another snap election given current parliamentary fragmentation, Macron's personal and political incentives, constitutional constraints, and the strategic responses of opposition parties. This perspective is crucial for weighing both institutional inertia and the rational calculus behind extraordinary political maneuvers.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.status_quo: No further snap legislative election is called before 2026. Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers and attempts to govern with an unstable, shifting minority, using negotiation and tactical concessions to avoid dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases the threshold for dissolution; only allows for snap elections after July 2025, reducing the window for action and making Macron less likely to call another snap election unless absolutely necessary.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate of Snap Dissolutions in Fifth Republic
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Historically, dissolutions are rare (only 5 under the Fifth Republic, with only two since 1968). This low base rate suggests that, even in turmoil, dissolution is not the default solution.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Political Incentives and Utility Calculation for Macron
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Macron already suffered a political backlash for the 2024 dissolution, which further fragmented the parliament and weakened his position. Polls and public reaction (majority opposed to another dissolution per Odysseus/Le Figaro survey) make another dissolution a high-risk, low-reward move. Macron’s rational incentive is to avoid further snap elections unless governance becomes totally impossible.

The extreme instability (five PMs in less than two years, repeated no-confidence votes, inability to pass budgets) increases the probability of another dissolution, especially if no government can survive even with shifting coalitions or technocratic appointments.

Street protests, union mobilization, and opposition calls for dissolution (Le Pen, Mélenchon) increase political pressure, but do not directly increase the likelihood unless they create an acute legitimacy crisis that cannot be managed by other means.

Opposition parties, especially the National Rally and the left, want snap elections but are also aware that further fragmentation could undermine their own power. If Macron perceives that a snap election would only strengthen his opponents or repeat the current deadlock, he is further deterred.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s Remaining Term and Legacy Calculation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: With the presidential election looming in 2027 and Macron constitutionally barred from running again, his incentive is to avoid major risks and focus on foreign policy or legacy projects, rather than provoke further domestic chaos.

Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.no_scenario: Despite ongoing instability, Macron continues to cycle through prime ministers, offering tactical concessions to the left or right as needed to secure temporary support and pass minimal budgets. The National Assembly remains deadlocked but not so dysfunctional as to make governance totally impossible. Macron calculates that another snap election would likely reproduce the current fragmentation or strengthen his opponents, so he refrains from dissolution. The year ends without a new call for elections.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.yes_scenario: Mounting instability—such as the failure of multiple governments in rapid succession, inability to pass a budget, and mass strikes escalating into unmanageable unrest—convinces Macron that only a new popular mandate can break the deadlock. Facing the impossibility of forming any viable coalition or technocratic government, and perhaps under acute market or EU pressure, Macron dissolves the National Assembly and calls for a snap election before January 1, 2026.
Political Science (Rational Choice Theor.final_reasoning: While France is experiencing extraordinary instability, with five PMs in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, and mass protests, the base rate for dissolutions under the Fifth Republic remains low, and the constitutional window for action is narrow. Macron’s personal and political incentives, as well as public opinion, strongly discourage another dissolution, especially given the backlash after the 2024 snap election. Rational choice logic suggests he will only take such a drastic step if all other routes to minimal governance are exhausted. The news indicates that, despite instability, Macron has so far opted for appointing new PMs and seeking ad hoc parliamentary support rather than dissolution. While the probability is elevated compared to a normal year, it is still below even odds. The only scenario in which Macron would rationally call another snap election is one of total paralysis or acute crisis (e.g., inability to pass a budget, unmanageable unrest, or financial markets/EU forcing his hand), for which there is not yet clear evidence. I therefore assign a probability somewhat higher than the historical base rate (to reflect the unusual level of instability), but well below 50%.

Political Science (Coalition Theory).perspective_relevance: As a political scientist specializing in Coalition Theory, I focus on the stability of parliamentary systems under fragmented legislatures, the strategic incentives facing presidents in semi-presidential systems, and the historical patterns of coalition breakdowns leading to early elections. This expertise allows me to evaluate whether France’s current parliamentary deadlock and recurrent government collapses make another snap election before 2026 a likely strategic move for Macron—or whether political constraints and base rates make this unlikely.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).status_quo: No new snap legislative election is called before 2026. Macron and successive minority governments muddle through by cobbling together support on a vote-by-vote basis, despite instability.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The French Constitution prohibits another dissolution for one year after the last snap election. This means the earliest a new dissolution could be called is July 2025, compressing the window for action to only about six months before question close.
Decreases probability: Historically, snap dissolutions are rare in France; only a handful have occurred since 1958, and two in quick succession is unprecedented.

Mixed: Macron’s prior dissolution backfired, strengthening opposition parties and leaving his coalition weaker. Polls and public opinion (noted in the Odysseus Institute survey) are against another dissolution. He also faces presidential term limits in 2027, reducing personal incentive to risk a new election. However, if the Assembly becomes completely unmanageable or if cohabitation is preferable to instability, he could see dissolution as a last resort.

Increases probability: With five PMs in two years, recurrent no-confidence votes, and inability to pass budgets (the core function of the Assembly), the structural deadlock increases the risk of political collapse and a new election.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and Elite Backlash to Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The public overwhelmingly opposes another dissolution (62% per Odysseus Institute), and political elites fear further destabilization. Macron may fear that calling another snap election would further delegitimize the presidency and empower the extremes (RN or LFI).

Increases probability: Economic crisis (debt, budget impasse, ratings downgrades), social unrest (mass protests), and EU pressure could force Macron’s hand if governance becomes impossible, making dissolution politically justifiable despite risks.

Decreases probability: Macron can keep appointing minority PMs, reshuffling cabinets, or seeking ad hoc cross-bloc deals, even if unstable. As long as basic governance is possible and the Assembly does not totally paralyze the executive, he is likely to avoid dissolution.

Political Science (Coalition Theory).no_scenario: Despite recurring government collapses and protests, Macron appoints successive technocratic or centrist minority governments (as he has repeatedly done), relying on shifting alliances and concessions to pass essential budgets. The Assembly continues to threaten censures, but no bloc wants to risk a new election, and Macron—burned by his last dissolution and facing public hostility to another—opts for muddling through. The window for calling a new snap election closes without action.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).yes_scenario: The Lecornu government collapses rapidly (potentially in October-December 2025), and the Assembly proves completely ungovernable: no PM can secure a majority or even regular ad hoc support, and essential business (budget, debt financing, EU requirements) stalls. External pressures mount (market panic, EU sanctions, mass strikes). Macron concludes that only a new election can break the deadlock, and—despite risks—calls a snap legislative election before January 1, 2026.
Political Science (Coalition Theory).final_reasoning: The base rate for consecutive dissolutions in France is extremely low, and the one-year constitutional ban compressed the decision window to the second half of 2025. Macron’s last snap election failed, leaving him weaker, and both public and elite opinion are strongly against another dissolution. However, government instability has reached unprecedented levels (five PMs in two years, repeated no-confidence votes, and inability to pass the budget), and the opposition continues to threaten further censures. The articles highlight mounting economic and social crises, but also suggest that Macron continues to prefer appointing new PMs, avoiding dissolution as long as possible. While the scenario for a Yes outcome is plausible if the Assembly becomes totally dysfunctional, the strong status quo bias, political risks, and available alternatives for muddling through make a new snap election before 2026 unlikely—but not impossible. Given all factors, the probability is higher than the historical base rate, but still below even odds.

Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.perspective_relevance: As an expert in French SemiPresidentialism, I analyze the interplay between the president and parliament, the constitutional powers to dissolve the National Assembly, and the dynamics of government formation in fragmented legislatures. I bring a nuanced understanding of the Fifth Republic's institutional resilience, the strategic calculus of presidential dissolutions, and the historical use (and avoidance) of snap elections as a political tool in times of gridlock.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.status_quo: No snap election is called. The current unstable minority/coalition government muddles through with repeated no-confidence threats, short-lived prime ministers, and legislative stagnation, but Macron avoids another dissolution.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French constitution prevents a new dissolution for a year after the last one (July 2024–July 2025). With only a short time window left before January 2026, this constraint has made snap elections less likely for much of the forecast period.

Decreases probability. The 2024 dissolution is widely seen as a political error, with 62% of French people opposing another dissolution before 2027 (Le Figaro/Institut Odysseus poll). Macron is likely to be highly reluctant to repeat what is widely viewed as a failed gambit, especially given the reputational damage.

Increases probability. The Assembly is highly fractured (no bloc near 289 seats; five PMs in 21 months), and every government since 2024 has fallen to no-confidence votes or been threatened by them. If a government cannot pass a budget or function at all, Macron may feel dissolution is the only escape.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Risk of Far-Right Gains in New Elections
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Both Macron and much of the political class fear that new elections would further benefit the National Rally, which is already strong and could win a plurality or even majority. This risk makes dissolution unappealing unless all other avenues have failed.

Slightly increases probability. The left and right (esp. National Rally) are both calling for dissolution, and public unrest (strikes, mass protests) continues. If Macron loses all capacity to govern (budget impasse, widespread social crisis), he may yield to pressure.

Decreases probability. Macron is term-limited and has little to gain from risking a new election that could hand power to his opponents and further damage his legacy. He may prefer muddling through, appointing technocratic governments, or tolerating stalemates.

Decreases probability. In the Fifth Republic, dissolutions have been rare and generally avoided unless the president is confident of winning. Two dissolutions within 18 months would be unprecedented and would signal constitutional crisis.

Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.no_scenario: Despite continued instability (frequent government collapses, difficulty passing budgets, ongoing protests), Macron avoids calling another snap election before Jan 1, 2026. Instead, he repeatedly appoints technocratic or minority governments that limp along, using Article 49.3 or ad hoc coalitions to pass essential legislation. Macron prefers to ride out the storm and avoid risking a further boost to the National Rally, even if it means ongoing stalemate and unpopularity.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.yes_scenario: The Lecornu government (or a subsequent replacement) is toppled by a no-confidence vote, and no viable coalition or technocratic government can secure a parliamentary majority or pass a budget. Faced with an ungovernable Assembly, escalating strikes, and the threat of EU fiscal penalties, Macron concludes that dissolution is the least-bad option and calls another snap election before January 1, 2026, hoping for a less fragmented outcome.
Political Science (French SemiPresidenti.final_reasoning: The status quo strongly favors no further dissolution: the constitutional one-year rule left only a six-month window, and Macron already paid a heavy price for the 2024 snap election. Public opinion is firmly against another dissolution, and there is significant fear (on the part of the president and the political mainstream) of empowering the National Rally in a new vote. While gridlock and instability are extreme—no stable government, frequent no-confidence votes, and mass protest—the Fifth Republic's design allows for persistent deadlock without necessarily triggering a new election. Macron's incentive is to avoid another dissolution unless absolutely unavoidable, and the historical base rate for repeated snap dissolutions is near zero. The only plausible trigger for a new election would be total governmental paralysis, with no prime minister able to survive a confidence vote, no budget passed, and overwhelming social or market pressure. While this scenario is not impossible, it requires several additional steps of escalation beyond the current deadlock. Given the short window left and the strong institutional and political disincentives, the probability that Macron will call another snap election before Jan 1, 2026 is low, but not negligible given France’s current turmoil.

Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.perspective_relevance: My expertise in comparative executive-legislative relations is highly relevant, as the question centers on whether the French president will dissolve parliament and call new elections—a core executive-legislative maneuver. Understanding the French Fifth Republic’s constitutional provisions, the mechanisms and incentives for dissolution, historical precedents, coalition stability, and the political calculus of presidents and parliamentary coalitions is crucial for an accurate forecast.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The French constitution only allows one dissolution per year, and further, presidents are historically reluctant to use this tool in quick succession due to the destabilizing effects and political risks (particularly after the 2024 experience).

Increases probability. France has had five prime ministers in two years, frequent government collapse, and no stable majority. If repeated no-confidence votes make forming or sustaining a government impossible, Macron may have no alternative but to call new elections.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public and Elite Sentiment on Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent polling shows 62% of French citizens oppose another early election, and the 2024 snap election is widely seen as a political error that weakened Macron and the government. Elite opinion (including within Macron’s own coalition) is wary of repeating the process.

Increases probability. Both the far-right and far-left are pushing for dissolution as a way to break the deadlock or gain advantage, and Macron could be tempted to gamble on a better result if the current situation becomes truly ungovernable.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Macron’s Political Capital and Legacy Concerns
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Macron’s popularity is at historic lows; another failed snap election could further damage his legacy and embolden rivals. He may prefer to limp through to 2027, focusing on foreign policy and letting the next government inherit the crisis.
Decreases probability. Since the Fifth Republic’s founding, multiple dissolutions in a short period are exceedingly rare; back-to-back dissolutions within two years have never occurred.

Mixed. Economic crisis and mass protests raise pressure for a solution, but may also make politicians more risk-averse and less likely to risk an election that could produce an even more unworkable parliament.

Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.no_scenario: Despite ongoing instability, Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers and negotiate ad hoc coalitions or allow governments to work in a caretaker capacity. The left and right threaten censure, but because of mutual distrust and fear of triggering a National Rally victory, no single grouping pushes hard enough to force Macron’s hand. Macron, wary of the political and economic risks, avoids calling another snap election and instead muddles through until the regular 2026 election.
Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.yes_scenario: Parliament becomes completely unworkable: a key budget fails, no government can survive a confidence vote, and mass protests paralyze the country. Elite and public pressure builds, and perhaps the Socialists or moderate right indicate they would support dissolution. Macron, out of options and facing an outright governmental shutdown, dissolves the Assembly to try to break the deadlock, even at the risk of empowering the opposition.
Comparative Politics (ExecutiveLegislati.final_reasoning: The French executive is facing perhaps unprecedented instability: five PMs in two years, repeated government collapse, and a parliament divided into three hostile blocs. The constitutional right to dissolve the Assembly is a powerful tool, but the 2024 dissolution is widely considered a political disaster for Macron, and public/elite appetite for another election is low. The base rate for back-to-back dissolutions is extremely low, and the risk for Macron’s legacy is enormous. However, the government is teetering on the edge of ungovernability, and if no government can survive, dissolution may become the least-bad option. On balance, the likelihood is significantly higher than in normal times—instability is extreme—but still less than even odds, given the strong status quo bias, public opposition, and Macron’s likely risk aversion. The probability should be bold—reflecting the unique instability—but not extreme, given the base rate and multiple off-ramps to muddling through.

Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Comparative Politics with a focus on Government Stability Models, my approach emphasizes the structural and historical determinants of executive-legislative relations, the durability of minority and caretaker governments, and the role of institutional constraints and incentives (such as constitutional rules on dissolution and historical base rates of early elections). This perspective allows me to contextualize France’s current instability within broader patterns of parliamentary gridlock, executive strategy, and crisis management found in other semi-presidential systems.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.status_quo: No snap legislative election is called before 2026. Despite instability, presidents of the Fifth Republic have rarely used the dissolution power more than once per term, and there is a strong institutional and political bias toward muddling through with weak, short-lived governments rather than repeatedly returning to the polls.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The constitution prohibits another dissolution within a year of the last, which elapsed in July 2025. While this window is now open, the recent memory of a destabilizing snap election and its political backlash makes another dissolution in 2025 less attractive.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Base Rate of Repeated Dissolutions
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. In the Fifth Republic, no president has called two snap legislative elections in close succession. Most presidents avoid repeated dissolutions due to the risk of further strengthening anti-establishment forces and public backlash.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Extreme Political Fragmentation and Executive Weakness
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. The National Assembly has seen at least five PMs in two years, repeated no-confidence motions, budget standoffs, and mass protests. This heightens the risk that government formation fails completely, potentially leaving dissolution as the last resort.

Decreases probability. Recent polling and reporting indicate strong public opposition to another snap election so soon after the last, with most blaming Macron for the current instability. Calling another dissolution could further erode legitimacy and risk political suicide.

Ambiguous. The far-right National Rally and some left-wing leaders publicly call for dissolution, but others may prefer to let Macron bear the weight of the crisis, betting on further erosion of his coalition before 2027. This reduces unified pressure for an immediate dissolution.

Decreases probability. Macron is described as having regretted the prior dissolution, and the major blocs are highly unlikely to provide him with a working majority following another election. He may prefer to limp along with technocratic or minority governments, focusing on foreign policy.

Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.no_scenario: Despite multiple government collapses and recurring budget crises, Macron manages to keep appointing new (possibly technocratic or caretaker) prime ministers, relying on ad hoc support or abstentions to pass minimal legislation. The opposition prefers to avoid elections, public opinion is hostile to another dissolution, and Macron avoids further damaging his legitimacy before 2027. The Assembly remains deadlocked, but no further snap election is called before the end of 2025.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.yes_scenario: All attempts at government formation fail catastrophically: no prime minister can survive a confidence vote, the 2026 budget cannot be passed, and France faces escalating social unrest and bond market pressure. Macron, with no viable options and mounting external and internal crises, calls for another dissolution in late 2025 to break the deadlock, despite public opposition and personal political risk.
Comparative Politics (Government Stabili.final_reasoning: The current French political situation is extremely unstable: five PMs in two years, serial government collapses, and a hung parliament. However, the Fifth Republic’s structure, the constitutional one-year rule (now expired), and historical precedent all create a strong bias against repeated dissolutions. Moreover, public opinion is overwhelmingly hostile to another snap election, and Macron has little to gain—he is unlikely to secure a more favorable majority, and another dissolution could be seen as reckless or desperate, risking further loss of legitimacy. The base rate for two dissolutions in a short window is near zero in modern French history. While the chance is non-negligible—particularly if government formation becomes literally impossible and France faces acute fiscal or social crisis—the far more likely outcome is continued muddling through with weak, short-lived governments or technocratic caretakers. Therefore, I judge the probability of Macron calling another snap legislative election before 2026 at 15%.

French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.time_to_resolution: Approximately 2.5 months (question closes Jan 1, 2026; today is Oct 15, 2025)
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.perspective_relevance: As an expert in French Studies specializing in Fifth Republic Constitutional Analysis, I bring a strong understanding of both the legal mechanisms available to the president (i.e., Article 12 powers, constitutional limits on dissolution frequency, traditions of 'dissolution d'opportunité' and 'dissolution de crise'), as well as the historical context and base rates for dissolutions. I also understand the political calculus Macron faces: risks of further delegitimization, the precedent and consequences of frequent dissolutions, and the constitutional and political constraints shaping his options.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.status_quo: No new snap election called before 2026. Macron called a snap election in July 2024, leading to a fragmented Assembly; multiple governments have fallen since, but to date, no further dissolution has occurred. The default baseline is political muddling-through, with minority governments falling and being replaced, but no new election.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The constitution forbids another dissolution for a year after the last one (July 2024-July 2025). That window has only just reopened, meaning the historical base rate for dissolutions in such close succession is extremely low.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Historical Base Rate for Double Dissolution
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Since 1958, no president has dissolved the Assembly twice in one term, let alone within two years. Macron’s 2024 dissolution was already rare; a second snap election before his term’s end would be unprecedented.

Decreases probability. Polls cited in recent articles show a large majority of the public disapproves of the last dissolution and opposes another before 2027. Macron’s popularity is at historic lows; another snap election risks further delegitimization, especially as repeated dissolutions are seen as a sign of executive failure.

Increases probability. France has had 5 prime ministers in 21 months, and the Assembly is deadlocked. The latest government is already facing no-confidence threats. If no government can be formed and the Assembly proves unworkable, constitutional logic and political pressure could push Macron to dissolve again.

Increases probability. Both the far-right National Rally (Le Pen) and the far-left (LFI) are agitating for dissolution, seeing an opportunity to improve their position. If a government falls and no viable coalition emerges, pressure may mount for a new election.

Slightly decreases probability. Macron has few good options: a new election could hand more seats to the far-right or far-left, but continued instability also damages his legacy. However, given the risks of further electoral defeat and the lack of public appetite, he is incentivized to avoid dissolution unless absolutely cornered.

Decreases probability. The French constitution and political tradition allow for cohabitation (a government from the opposition), which is a pressure valve. If Macron cannot govern with a centrist, he can appoint a PM from the majority bloc (left or RN), making a new election less necessary.

French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.no_scenario: Despite ongoing government crises, Macron continues to appoint new prime ministers or allows a form of cohabitation, with minority governments muddling through. Each time a government falls, Macron resists opposition calls for dissolution, fearing electoral backlash and remembering the public’s disapproval of the July 2024 snap election. The Assembly remains fragmented, but at least a caretaker government or a technocratic/consensus arrangement endures until the regular 2027 election. Macron is further weakened, but the status quo of instability and gridlock persists.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.yes_scenario: The current government (Lecornu or successor) falls to a no-confidence vote, and after repeated failed attempts to form a new majority, the Assembly is paralyzed. Macron, under intense public, market, and opposition pressure, and unable to form even a minimally functional government, concludes that only dissolution offers a way out. He calls a snap election before the end of 2025, hoping to break the deadlock—even at the risk of further boosting the opposition.
French Studies (Fifth Republic Constitut.final_reasoning: The recent news highlights unprecedented instability: five PMs in under two years, repeated government collapses, and a highly fragmented Assembly. The constitutional bar on dissolutions has just been lifted, so a snap election is now technically possible. However, the historical base rate for two dissolutions in a single presidential term is essentially zero, and public opinion is strongly against another snap election so soon. Macron’s political capital is at a nadir, and his incentives are to avoid another dissolution unless absolutely necessary. The French constitutional tradition and the possibility of cohabitation provide alternative ways to manage deadlock, making a second dissolution a last resort. While the instability is severe and pressure is mounting, there is still room for muddling through, caretaker governments, or even a left- or right-wing cohabitation. Only if all other options fail, and the Assembly is utterly paralyzed with no government able to survive even a few months, would Macron dare to dissolve again. Given the base rate, constitutional logic, and political calculus, the probability is higher than in normal times but still clearly below even odds. I assess the probability of Macron calling another snap election before January 1, 2026 at 25%.
